articles.headline: Trump Health Aide Pushes Bizarre Conspiracies and Warns of Armed Revolt
articles.snippet: Michael R. Caputo told a Facebook audience without evidence that left-wing hit squads were being trained for insurrection and accused C.D.C. scientists of “sedition.”
articles.abstract: Michael R. Caputo told a Facebook audience without evidence that left-wing hit squads were being trained for insurrection and accused C.D.C. scientists of “sedition.”

articles.headline: U.S. Restricts Chinese Apparel and Tech Products, Citing Forced Labor
articles.snippet: The new restrictions, announced Monday, fall short of a broader ban on cotton and tomatoes from Xinjiang that the administration was poised to announce last week.
articles.abstract: The new restrictions, announced Monday, fall short of a broader ban on cotton and tomatoes from Xinjiang that the administration was poised to announce last week.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration on Monday announced new restrictions on imports of apparel, hair products and technology goods from certain Chinese companies, saying those entities had used forced labor in the Xinjiang region to make their products.

articles.headline: TikTok’s Proposed Deal Seeks to Mollify U.S. and China
articles.snippet: The Chinese-owned app designed a compromise to satisfy U.S. security concerns. The terms are now under review by the Trump administration.
articles.abstract: The Chinese-owned app designed a compromise to satisfy U.S. security concerns. The terms are now under review by the Trump administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After more than six weeks, two White House executive orders, new Chinese regulations and multiple bidders, a deal for the social media app TikTok has boiled down to one main strategy: mitigation.
articles.byline: By David McCabe, Ana Swanson and Erin Griffith

articles.headline: As Trump Again Rejects Science, Biden Calls Him a ‘Climate Arsonist’
articles.snippet: The president visited California after weeks of silence on its wildfires and blamed the crisis only on poor forest management, not climate change. “I don’t think science knows” what is happening, he said.
articles.abstract: The president visited California after weeks of silence on its wildfires and blamed the crisis only on poor forest management, not climate change. “I don’t think science knows” what is happening, he said.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Follow our daily updates on the latest presidential election polls.]
articles.byline: By Peter Baker, Lisa Friedman and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: Coming This Fall: Return of the Video Game Console Wars
articles.snippet: Gamers are awaiting Sony’s PlayStation 5 and Microsoft’s Xbox Series X, though supply might be limited because of the pandemic.
articles.abstract: Gamers are awaiting Sony’s PlayStation 5 and Microsoft’s Xbox Series X, though supply might be limited because of the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — Even before the coronavirus forced the world indoors and glued millions of people to their screens, 2020 was shaping up to be a huge year for gaming.

articles.headline: Struggling Hotel Owners, Some With Trump Ties, Seek Federal Bailout
articles.snippet: Hotel owners, who spent years loading up on a cheap type of debt, are now faced with the potential for default as the pandemic saps revenues.
articles.abstract: Hotel owners, who spent years loading up on a cheap type of debt, are now faced with the potential for default as the pandemic saps revenues.
articles.lead_paragraph: Thomas J. Barrack Jr., the billionaire investor and major donor to President Trump, has run into an unexpected patch of red ink thanks to the pandemic: He has struggled to keep up with payments on $1.97 billion in Wall Street debt he used to buy a collection of more than 160 hotels.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: How Companies Are Getting Speedy Coronavirus Tests for Employees
articles.snippet: Intermediaries are finding labs with capacity for companies seeking to make sure workers are virus-free. But many employers choose to avoid the cost.
articles.abstract: Intermediaries are finding labs with capacity for companies seeking to make sure workers are virus-free. But many employers choose to avoid the cost.
articles.lead_paragraph: As businesses try to recover from the pandemic’s economic blow while ensuring the safety of workers and customers, many have complained of two obstacles: access to coronavirus testing for their employees and long delays in receiving results.

articles.headline: Diversity Push Barely Budges Corporate Boards to 12.5%, Survey Finds
articles.snippet: Despite pledges to nominate more members of underrepresented ethnic and racial groups, companies have made little progress over the last five years.
articles.abstract: Despite pledges to nominate more members of underrepresented ethnic and racial groups, companies have made little progress over the last five years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Corporations in the United States have pledged for years to increase the number of Hispanic, Black, Asian-American and other underrepresented members on their boards, which make decisions that affect the livelihoods of millions. Yet a comprehensive new survey finds that they have made little progress.

articles.headline: Justice Dept. Opens Criminal Inquiry Into John Bolton’s Book
articles.snippet: Investigators are examining whether the former national security adviser illegally disclosed classified information.
articles.abstract: Investigators are examining whether the former national security adviser illegally disclosed classified information.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department has opened a criminal investigation into whether President Trump’s former national security adviser John R. Bolton unlawfully disclosed classified information in a memoir this summer, an inquiry that the department began after it failed to stop the book’s publication, according to three people familiar with the matter.

articles.headline: ‘Nothing to Do With Climate Change’: Conservative Media and Trump Align on Fires
articles.snippet: Rush Limbaugh and Tucker Carlson dismiss scientists’ determination that climate change is a key culprit in West Coast wildfires.
articles.abstract: Rush Limbaugh and Tucker Carlson dismiss scientists’ determination that climate change is a key culprit in West Coast wildfires.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rush Limbaugh told millions of his radio listeners to set aside any suggestion that climate change was the culprit for the frightening spate of wildfires ravaging California and the Pacific Northwest.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Tiffany Hsu

articles.headline: Even as Cases Rise, Europe Is Learning to Live With the Coronavirus
articles.snippet: Protections like wearing masks, which have proved divisive in the United States, are now widespread on the continent, helping people get on with their lives with calculated risk.
articles.abstract: Protections like wearing masks, which have proved divisive in the United States, are now widespread on the continent, helping people get on with their lives with calculated risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — In the early days of the pandemic, President Emmanuel Macron exhorted the French to wage “war” against the coronavirus. Today, his message is to “learn how to live with the virus.”
